speaker: Doctor
text: Can you please tell me more about the attention issues and change in behavior your mother is concerned about, when did you first notice these changes? What were you doing when you noticed them?

speaker: Patient
text: "I guess it started when I began high school, everything just seemed so overwhelming and I couldn't focus like I used to. I'd be sitting in class trying to take notes, but my mind would just wander off and I wouldn't remember what the teacher was saying. My mom got really upset when she saw my report card, that's when she started saying I had attention issues."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must have been really tough for you, especially with the added pressure from your mom. Can you tell me more about what's going on when your mind wanders off, do you find yourself daydreaming or getting caught up in worries about something specific? Are you experiencing any other symptoms like headaches or difficulty sleeping?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't really know what's going on when my mind wanders off, it's just like my brain goes blank and I'm not really thinking about anything in particular. Sometimes I'll start thinking about stuff that's been bothering me, like fights with my friends or stressing about school, but it's not like I'm constantly worried about it or anything. And yeah, I have been having some trouble sleeping, I'll lie awake at night thinking about all the things I need to do the next day and it's hard to calm down."

speaker: Doctor
text: That sounds really frustrating, especially with the added stress of school and relationships. Can you tell me more about these fights with your friends, are they a new development or have you been having trouble getting along with them for a while? Have you noticed any other changes in your mood or emotions besides the stress and anxiety you mentioned?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I guess you could say it's pretty recent, we used to be really close but now it feels like we're just drifting apart. We don't really hang out as much as we used to and when we do, it's just not the same. And honestly, I've been feeling really irritable lately, even with my mom, which is why we get into fights all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by 'irritable', is it like you're feeling angry or frustrated all the time, or is it more that you're just really sensitive to things that wouldn't normally bother you? Are you finding yourself snapping at people or getting upset over small things?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I'd say it's a bit of both, I feel like I'm just really on edge all the time and little things can set me off. Like, my mom will ask me something simple and I'll just snap at her, or I'll get frustrated with my friends for no reason. It's not like I'm always angry, but I just feel really sensitive and overwhelmed, like everything is just too much to handle."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or energy levels, are you feeling more tired than usual or having trouble motivating yourself to do things you normally enjoy? Are there any other physical symptoms that you've been experiencing, like stomachaches or muscle tension?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I have been feeling really tired lately, even after sleeping for a long time. And it's hard to motivate myself to do things I used to enjoy, like cheerleading. I just don't feel like doing it anymore. As for appetite, I guess I've been eating less than usual, but it's not like I'm not hungry or anything, I just don't really feel like eating."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be really tough for you to feel so tired and unmotivated all the time. Can you tell me more about when you started feeling this way, was it around the same time that you began having attention issues in school? Have you experienced any significant events or changes in your life recently that could be contributing to how you're feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I think it started around the same time, when I began high school. Everything just felt so different and overwhelming, and I think that's when I started to feel really tired and unmotivated. As for significant events, I don't know... I guess you could say that starting high school was a big change for me, and maybe it's just been harder for me to adjust than I thought it would be."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the transition to high school has been a significant challenge for you. Can you tell me more about how you're handling the academic workload, are you feeling overwhelmed by the amount of homework or assignments you're receiving? Are there any particular subjects that you're struggling with or finding especially difficult?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, the homework can be really overwhelming at times. I feel like I'm spending so much time on it, but I'm still not doing very well. I'm really struggling with math and science, I just don't seem to understand the material as easily as I used to in middle school. And even when I do get it, I'll forget it by the next day, so it's hard to keep up."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be really frustrating for you, feeling like you're putting in a lot of effort but not seeing the results you want. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're trying to study or do homework, do you find yourself getting distracted easily or having trouble focusing on the material? Are you using any specific strategies or techniques to try and help you stay on track?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I get distracted really easily. I'll be sitting at my desk trying to do my homework, but then I'll start thinking about something else, like a conversation I had with a friend or a movie I saw over the weekend. And even when I try to focus, I just can't seem to keep my mind on the material. I've tried making flashcards and stuff, but it doesn't really seem to help. Sometimes I'll read a whole chapter in my textbook, but then I won't remember any of it because my mind was wandering the whole time."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be really tough for you, feeling like you're not able to retain the information even when you're trying your best. Can you tell me more about what's going on when you're reading a chapter in your textbook and your mind starts wandering, do you find yourself re-reading the same sentences over and over because you're not really taking it in? Are there any other situations where you feel like you're having trouble paying attention or following through on tasks?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, that's exactly what happens. I'll be reading a sentence, but by the time I get to the end of it, I've already forgotten what it said. So I'll go back and re-read it, but then the same thing happens again. It's like my brain is just not absorbing any of the information. And it's not just with schoolwork, either. Sometimes I'll be in the middle of a conversation with someone, and I'll just zone out and forget what we were talking about. It's really frustrating, because I feel like I'm missing out on things and people think I'm just not paying attention or that I'm not interested."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about how long these episodes of zoning out last, is it just for a few seconds or can it be for several minutes? And do you ever feel like you're able to snap back to attention and refocus, or does it take you a while to get back on track?

speaker: Patient
text: "Um, I'd say it can last for a few seconds to a few minutes, maybe even longer if I'm really caught up in my own thoughts. And sometimes I can snap back to attention pretty quickly, like if someone says my name or asks me a question, but other times it takes me a while to refocus and remember what's going on around me. It's kinda like I'm in my own little world and it's hard to come back to reality."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be really disorienting for you, feeling like you're coming in and out of focus like that. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "your own little world", is it a pleasant place or is it more of a stressful or anxious state? Are there any specific thoughts or feelings that you experience during these episodes that might help me understand what's going on?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's not really a pleasant place, I guess. It's just...my own thoughts, I suppose. I don't know, it's hard to explain. Sometimes I'll be thinking about stuff that's been bothering me, like school or friends, and sometimes I'll just be thinking about nothing in particular. It's not really stressful or anxious, it's just...distracted, I guess. Like my mind is elsewhere and I'm not really present in the moment. And when I come back to reality, it can be kinda overwhelming, like I've missed out on something important."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're experiencing a bit of a disconnect from the world around you during these episodes. Can you tell me more about what happens when you come back to reality and feel overwhelmed, do you experience any physical symptoms like a racing heart or sweating, or is it more of an emotional feeling of anxiety or panic? Are there any specific triggers that you've noticed that might contribute to these episodes, such as certain situations or environments?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, when I come back to reality and feel overwhelmed, I guess I would say it's more of an emotional feeling. I don't really experience any physical symptoms like a racing heart or sweating, but I do feel kinda anxious and panicked. It's like I've missed out on something important and I need to catch up, but I don't know what it is or how to do it. As for triggers, I'm not really sure...I think maybe certain situations or environments can contribute to it, like being in a crowded or noisy place. But sometimes it just happens out of nowhere, and that's even more frustrating because I don't know how to prepare for it or make it stop."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be really unsettling for you, feeling like these episodes can happen at any time without warning. Can you tell me more about how you've been coping with these feelings of anxiety and panic, have you found any strategies that help you calm down and refocus when you're feeling overwhelmed? Have you talked to anyone else about what you're experiencing, such as a school counselor or a trusted friend or family member?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I haven't really found anything that helps me cope with these feelings of anxiety and panic. I've tried taking deep breaths and trying to focus on the present moment, but it doesn't always work. And yeah, I've talked to my mom about it, but she just tells me to try harder and stay focused, which isn't really helpful. I haven't really talked to anyone else about it, though - I don't know, it's just hard for me to explain what's going on, and I don't want people to think I'm weird or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: It can be really tough to open up about struggles like this, especially when you're not sure how others will react. Have you considered talking to a school counselor or therapist who might be able to offer more specific guidance and support? Sometimes just having someone to talk to who understands what you're going through can make a big difference. REQUEST TEST: Anxiety Disorder Screening.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Patient scores do not suggest an anxiety disorder.

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know, thank you for sharing the results with me. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling physically, have you noticed any changes in your appetite or sleep patterns that might be contributing to your fatigue and difficulty focusing? Are there any other physical symptoms that you've been experiencing, such as headaches or stomachaches? REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count.

text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

text: That's good to know that the blood work came back normal. Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns, are you having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, and have you noticed any changes in your appetite or energy levels throughout the day? REQUEST TEST: Thyroid Function Test.

text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.

speaker: Doctor

Can you tell me more about your daily routine, are you getting any exercise or physical activity, and are you spending a lot of time on screens, such as phones or computers, before bedtime? Are there any other factors that you think might be contributing to your fatigue and difficulty focusing? REQUEST TEST: ADHD Screening.

text: RESULTS: Patient's symptoms do not align with a diagnosis of ADHD.

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like we've ruled out several potential causes for your symptoms, including anxiety disorder, thyroid issues, sleep disorders, and ADHD. Can you tell me more about your daily routine and how you're spending your time, are there any activities or habits that you think might be contributing to your fatigue and difficulty focusing? Are there any other factors in your life that have changed recently, such as a new job, move, or relationship, that could be impacting your mental and physical health? REQUEST TEST: Depression Screening.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Patient scores on the lower end, indicating no significant signs of depression.

speaker: Doctor
text:
DIAGNOSIS READY: Adjustment Disorder with mixed emotional features.

The majority of the doctors agree that the patient's symptoms are related to the stress and pressure of adjusting to high school, including academic and social challenges, and do not align with other potential underlying conditions such as anxiety disorder, depression, ADHD, or medical conditions. The normal test results for these conditions support this diagnosis. While some doctors mention considering other possibilities, such as Burnout or Executive Function Disorder, the overall consensus is that Adjustment Disorder is the most likely diagnosis. Cholecystitis is not mentioned in the discussion and is unrelated to the patient's symptoms.
